page.title: 9.2.0: Lesson Overview
page.contents:
In this lesson, you will learn that if we rearrange and rewrite the expression on one side of a quadratic equation to be a perfect square (that is, if we complete the square) we can find the solutions of the equation.

When you finish this lesson, you will be able to:

  • Explain what it means to "complete the square" and describe how to do it.
  • Solve quadratic equations by completing the square and finding square roots.

Here are the activities that will help you reach those goals:

  • 9.2.1: Different Forms of Perfect Squares
  • 9.2.2: Standard and Factored Forms of Perfect Squares
    • 9.2.2: Self Check
    • 9.2.2: Additional Resources
  • 9.2.3: Completing the Square
    • 9.2.3: Self Check
    • 9.2.3: Additional Resources
  • 9.2.4: Making a Perfect Square

After that, you'll practice and review.

  • 9.2.5: Practice
  • 9.2.6: Lesson Summary

page.title: 9.2.1: Different Forms of Perfect Squares
page.contents:
Warm Up Activity

  1. Select three expressions that are perfect squares. 

Correct! \((x+5)(5+x)\), \((x−3)^2\), \(x^2+8x+16\)

The correct answers are: \((x+5)(5+x)\), \((x−3)^2\), \(x^2+8x+16\).

  1. Explain how you know the expressions you selected are perfect squares.

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

Because each of them is the product of an expression and itself. \(x^2+8x+16\) is equivalent to \((x+4)(x+4)\).

page.title: 9.2.2: Standard and Factored Forms of Perfect Squares
page.contents:
Activity

  1. What is the factored form of \(x^2+6x+9\)?

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

\((x+3)^2\)


  1. What is the factored form of \(x^2−10x+25\)?

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

\((x−5)^2\)


  1. What is the standard form of \((x−7)^2\)?

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

\(x^2−14x+49\)


  1. What is the value of \(c\) in the expression \(x^2−20x+ c\)?

Enter the value of \(c\).

Correct! 100

The correct answer is 100.

  1. If \(x^2−20x+ c\) is factored to be \((x\; -\;\;\;)^2\), what is the missing value of the factored form of this expression?

Enter the missing value of the factored form.

Correct! 10

The correct answer is 10.

  1. What is the value of \(c\) in the expression \(x^2+16x+ c\)?

Enter the value of \(c\).

Correct! 64

The correct answer is 64.

  1. If \(x^2+16x+ c\) is factored to be \((x\; -\;\;\;)^2\), what is the missing value of the factored form of this expression?

Enter the missing value of the factored form.

Correct! 8

The correct answer is 8.

  1. What is the value of \(c\) in the expression \(x^2+7x+ c\)?

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

\(\frac{49}{4}\)


  1. If \(x^2+7x+ c\) is factored to be \((x\; -\;\;\;)^2\), what is the missing value of the factored form of this expression?

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

\(\frac72\)


  1. What is the value of \(c\) in the expression \(x^2+bx+ c\)?

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

\((\frac{b}{2})^2\)


  1. If \(x^2+bx+ c\) is factored to be \((x\; -\;\;\;)^2\), what is the missing value of the factored form of this expression?

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

\(\frac{b}{2}\)



Notice that finding the value of \(c\) helped to create a perfect square trinomial. This is called completing the square.

page.title: 9.2.2: Self Check
page.contents: Which value will create a perfect square trinomial when added to \(x^2-14x + \_\_\_\_\_\_\)?

answer.response: Incorrect. Let's try again a different way: After dividing the -14 by 2, square the -7. The answer is 49.
Incorrect. Let's try again a different way: When a negative is squared, it becomes positive. The answer is 49.
That's correct! Check yourself: Divide the -14 by 2 to get -7. When -7 is squared, it becomes 49.
Incorrect. Let's try again a different way: Divide the -14 by 2 before squaring it. The answer is 49.

page.title: 9.2.2: Additional Resources
page.contents:
Completing the Square

When a number is added to a quadratic expression to make a perfect square trinomial, that is called completing the square.

Here is how to complete the square of a quadratic expression, \(ax^2+bx+c\).

How to Complete a Square of \(x^2+bx\)

Step 1
Identify \(b\), the coefficient of \(x\).

Step 2
Find half of \(b\) and then square it. In other words, \((\frac{b}{2})^2\).

Step 3
Add the \((\frac{b}{2})^2\) to \(x^2+bx\).

Step 4
Factor the perfect square trinomial, writing it as a binomial squared.


Example

Complete the square to make a perfect square trinomial. Then write the result as a binomial squared.

\(x^2-26x\)

Step 1
Identify \(b\), the coefficient of \(x\).
The coefficient of \(x\) is -26.

Step 2
Find half of \(b\) and then square it. In other words, \((\frac{b}{2})^2\).
\((-\frac{26}{2})^2=(13)^2=169\)

Step 3
Add the \((\frac{b}{2})^2\) to \(x^2+bx\).
\(x^2-26x+169\)

Step 4
Factor the perfect square trinomial, writing it as a binomial squared.
\((x-13)^2\) 

Try It: Completing the Square

Complete the square to make a perfect square trinomial. Then, factor the trinomial.

\(x^2+8x+ \_\_\_\_\)

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Here is how to complete the square.

Step 1
Identify the coefficient of \(x\).
\(b=8\)

Step 2
Find \((\frac{b}{2})^2\).
\((\frac{8}{2})^2=4^2 =16\)

Step 3
Add the \((\frac{b}{2})^2\) to the \(x^2+bx\).
\(x^2+8x+ 16\)

Step 4
Factor the perfect square trinomial.
\((x+4)^2\)

answer.answer_text: I’d like to retry the self check.
I’m ready for the next activity.

page.title: 9.2.3: Completing the Square
page.contents:
Activity

One technique for solving quadratic equations is called completing the square. Here are two examples of how Diego and Mai completed the square to solve the same equation.

Diego:

\(\begin{aligned} x^{2}+10 x+9 &=0 \\ x^{2}+10 x &=-9 \\ x^{2}+10 x+25 &=-9+25 \\ x^{2}+10 x+25 &=16 \\ (x+5)^{2} &=16 \\ \sqrt{(x+5)^{2}} &=\sqrt{16} \\ x+5 &=\pm \;4 \\ \\ x+5=4 \text { or } x+5 &=-4 \\ x=-1 \text { and } x=-9 & \end{aligned}\)


Mai:

\(\begin{aligned} x^{2}+10 x+9 &=0 \\ x^{2}+10 x+9+16 &=16 \\ x^{2}+10 x+25 &=16 \\ (x+5)^{2} &=16 \\ \sqrt{(x+5)^{2}} &=\sqrt{16} \\ (x+5) &=\pm \;4 \\ \\ x+5=4 \text { and } x+5=-4 \\ x=-1 \text { or } x=-9 \end{aligned} \)


Study the worked examples. Then, try solving these equations by completing the square for questions 1–5.

  1. \(x^2+6x+8=0\)

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

\(\begin{aligned} x^{2}+6 x+8 &=0 \\ x^{2}+6 x &=-8 \\ x^{2}+6 x+9 &=-8+9 \\ (x+3)^{2} &=1 \\ \sqrt{(x+3)^{2}} &=\sqrt{1} \\ x+3 &=\pm \;1 \\ x+3 &=1 \\ x+3 &=-1 \\ \\ x=-4 & \text { and } x=-2 \end{aligned}\)



  1. \(x^2+12x=13\)

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

\(\begin{aligned} x^{2}+12 x &=13 \\ x^{2}+12 x+36 &=13+36 \\ x^{2}+12 x+36 &=49 \\ (x+6)^{2} &=49 \\ \sqrt{(x+6)^{2}} &=\sqrt{49} \\ x+6 &=\pm \;7 \\ x+6 &=7 \\ x+6 &=-7 \\ \\ x=-13 & \text { and } x=1 \end{aligned}\)



  1. \(0=x^2−10x+21\)

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

\(\begin{aligned} 0=\; & x^{2}-10 x+21 \\ x^{2}-10 x+21 &=0 \\ x^{2}-10 x &=-21 \\ x^{2}-10 x+25 &=-21+25 \\ x^{2}-10 x+25 &=4 \\ (x-5)^{2} &=4 \\ \sqrt{(x-5)^{2}} &=\sqrt{4} \\ x-5 &=\pm \;2 \\ x-5 &=2 \\ x-5 &=-2 \\ \\ x=3 & \text { and } x=7 \end{aligned}\)



  1. \(x^2−2x+3=83\)

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

\(\begin{aligned} x^{2}-2 x+3 &=83 \\ x^{2}-2 x &=83-3 \\ x^{2}-2 x &=80 \\ x^{2}-2 x+1 &=80+1 \\ x^{2}-2 x+1 &=81 \\ \sqrt{(x-1)^{2}} &=\sqrt{81} \\ x-1 &=\pm \;9 \\ x-1 &=9 \\ x-1 &=-9 \\ \\ x=-8 & \text { and } x=10 \end{aligned}\)



  1. \(x^2+40=14x\)

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

\(\begin{aligned} x^{2}+40 &=14 x \\ x^{2}-14 x+40 &=0 \\ x^{2}-14 x &=-40 \\ x^{2}-14 x+49 &=-40+49 \\ x^{2}-14 x+49 &=9 \\ \sqrt{(x-7)^{2}} &=\sqrt{9} \\ x-7 &=\pm \;3 \\ x-7 &=3 \\ x-7 &=-3 \\ \\ x=4 & \text { and } x=10 \end{aligned}\)




Extending Your Thinking

Here is a diagram made of a square and two congruent rectangles. Its total area is \(x^2+35x\) square units.

Diagram A

  1. What is the length of the unlabeled side of each of the two rectangles in Diagram A?

Enter the length of the unlabeled side of each of the two rectangles.

Compare your answer:

17.5


  1. In Diagram B, we add lines to make the figure a square. The area of the square becomes a quadratic equation.

Calculate the equation, then put that equation in the standard form \(ax^2+bx+c\) to answer questions a and b.

  1. Using the standard form \(ax^2+bx+c\) to represent the area of the square in Diagram B, what is the value of the coefficient \(b\)?  

Enter the value of the coefficient \(b\).

Compare your answer:

35


  1. Using the standard form \(ax^2+bx+c\) to represent the area of the square in Diagram B, what is the value of the constant \(c\)?  

Enter the value of the constant \(c\).

Compare your answer:

306.25


  1. How is the process of finding the area of the entire figure like the process of building perfect squares for expressions like \(x^2+bx\)?

Enter your explanation of how the two processes are alike.

Compare your answer:

First, we had to figure out what number was half of 35 (which is 17.5) to find the side length of the rectangles. Then, we had to square the number 17.5 to find the area of the missing piece.


Video: Solve Equations by Completing the Square

Watch the following video to learn more about solving equations by completing the square.

page.title: 9.2.3: Self Check
page.contents: Find the solutions to \(x^2-10x=-9\) by completing the square.

answer.response: Incorrect. Let's try again a different way: This is the value of \((\frac{b}{2})^2\). The correct answer is \(x=1\), \(x=9\).

That's correct! Check yourself: Add 25 to each side to create a perfect square trinomial. The equation becomes \((x-5)^2=16\). Taking the square root of each side, the equation becomes \(x-5= \pm \;4\). This results in two solutions.
Incorrect. Let's try again a different way: After adding -9 and 25, remember to take the square root of both sides. The correct answer is \(x=1\), \(x=9\).
Incorrect. Let's try again a different way: There are two solutions. Remember to use the plus/minus sign when using the square root property. The correct answer is \(x=1\), \(x=9\).

page.title: 9.2.3: Additional Resources
page.contents:
Solving Quadratic Equations by Completing the Square

Example

Solve \(x^2+8x=48\) by completing the square.

Step 1
Isolate the variable terms on one side and place the constant term on the other.
This equation has all the variables on the left.
\({\style{color:red}a}{\style{color:red}x}^{\style{color:red}2}\;{\style{color:red}+}\;{\style{color:red}b}{\style{color:red}x}\;{\style{color:red}=}\;{\style{color:red}c}\)
\(x^2+8x=48\)

Step 2
Find (\(\frac{b}{2})^2\), the number to complete the square. Add to both sides of the equation.
Take half of 8 and square it.
\(4^2=16\)
Add 16 to BOTH sides of the equation.
\(x^2+8x+ \_\_\_\_ =48\)
\((\frac{b}{2})^2\)
\(x^2+8x \;{\style{color:red}+}\;{\style{color:red}1}{\style{color:red}6} =48 \;{\style{color:red}+}\;{\style{color:red}1}{\style{color:red}6}\)

Step 3
Factor the perfect square trinomial as a binomial square.
\(x^2+8x+16=(x+4)^2\)
Substitute the binomial square term for the trinomial.
\((x+4)^2=64\)

Step 4
Use the square root property.
\(\sqrt{(x+4)^2}=\sqrt{64}\)
\(x+4= \pm \;8\)

Step 5
Simplify the radical and then solve the two resulting equations.
\(x+4= \pm \;8\)
\(x+4=8\)          \(x+4=-8\)
\(x =4\)             \(x=-12\)

Step 6
Check the solutions.
Put each answer in the original equation to check.

Substitute \(x=4\).
\(x^2+8x=48\)
\(({\style{color:red}4})^2+8({\style{color:red}4}) ≟ 48\)
\(16+32 ≟ 48\)
\(48=48 ✔\)

Substitute \(x=-12\).
\(x^2+8x=48\)
\(({\style{color:red}-}{\style{color:red}1}{\style{color:red}2})^2+8({\style{color:red}-}{\style{color:red}1}{\style{color:red}2}) ≟ 48\)
\(144-96 ≟ 48\)
\(48=48 ✔\)

Try It: Solving Quadratic Equations by Completing the Square

Solve \(x^2+4x=5\) by completing the square.

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Here is how to solve this quadratic using completing the square:

Step 1
Isolate the constants on one side of the equation.
\(x^2+4x=5\) 

Step 2
Find \((\frac{b}{2})^2\). Add this number to both sides of the equation.
\(b=4\), \((\frac{4}{2})^2=2^2=4\)
\(x^2+4x+4=5+4\)
\(x^2+4x+4=9\) 

Step 3
Factor the perfect square trinomial.
\((x+2)^2=9\)

Step 4
Use the square root property.
\(\sqrt{(x+2)^2}=9\)
\(x+2= \pm \;3\)

Step 5
Separate into two equations and solve.
\(x+2=-3\)          \(x+2=3\)
\(x =-5\)             \(x=1\)

Step 6
Check into the original equation.
\(x=-5\)
\((-5)^2+4(-5)=5\)
\(25+-20=5\)

\(x=1\)
\(1^2+4(1)=5\)
\(5=5\)

answer.answer_text: I’d like to retry the self check.
I’m ready for the next activity.

page.title: 9.2.4: Making a Perfect Square
page.contents:
Cool Down Activity

For questions 1–3, what could be added to each expression to make it a perfect square?

  1. \(x^2+12x\)

Enter what could be added to make the expression a perfect square.

Correct! The constant term \(c=36\) can be added to make the perfect square \(x^2+12x+36\).

The correct answer is: The constant term \(c=36\) can be added to make the perfect square \(x^2+12x+36\).

  1. \(x^2−6x+1\)

Enter what could be added to make the expression a perfect square.

Correct! 8 can be added to the constant term \(c=1\) to make the perfect square \(x^2-6x+9\).

The correct answer is: 8 can be added to the constant term \(c=1\) to make the perfect square \(x^2-6x+9\).

  1. \(x^2+14x−10\)

Enter what could be added to make the expression a perfect square.

Correct! 59 can be added to the constant term \(c=-10\) to make the perfect square \(x^2+14x+49\).

The correct answer is: 59 can be added to the constant term \(c=-10\) to make the perfect square \(x^2+14x+49\).

  1. Solve the equation \(x^2−16x=-60\) by completing the square. Show your reasoning.

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

\(\begin{aligned} x^{2}-16 x &=-60 \\ x^{2}-16 x+64 &=-60+64 \\ x^{2}-16 x+64 &=4 \\ (x-8)^{2} &=4 \\ \sqrt{(x-8)^{2}} &=\sqrt{4} \\ x-8 &=\pm 2 \\ x-8 &=2 \\ x-8 &=-2 \\ \\ x=6 & \text { or } x=10 \end{aligned}\)

page.title: 9.2.5: Practice
page.contents:
Complete the following questions to practice the skills you have learned in this lesson.

  1. The standard form of an equation is \(ax^2+bx+c\). For each expression, find the missing constant \(c\) that would make the expression a perfect square.
  1. \(x^2−6x+ \underline{\;\;c\;\;}\)

Correct! 9 can be added to make the expression a perfect square.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 9.2.4. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is: 9 can be added to make the expression a perfect square. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. \(x^2+2x+ \underline{\;\;c\;\;}\)

Correct! 1 can be added to make the expression a perfect square.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 9.2.4. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is: 1 can be added to make the expression a perfect square. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. \(x^2+14x+ \underline{\;\;c\;\;}\)

Correct! 49 can be added to make the expression a perfect square.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 9.2.4. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is: 49 can be added to make the expression a perfect square. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. \(x^2−4x+ \underline{\;\;c\;\;}\)

Correct! 4 can be added to make the expression a perfect square.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 9.2.4. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is: 4 can be added to make the expression a perfect square. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. \(x^2+24x+ \underline{\;\;c\;\;}\)

Correct! 144 can be added to make the expression a perfect square.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 9.2.4. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is: 144 can be added to make the expression a perfect square. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. For each expression, find the missing piece of information, including the sign, in the factored form \((x\_\_\_\_\_)^2\).
  1. If \(x^2−6x+c\) is factored to be \((x \_\_\_\_\_)^2\), what is the missing value of the factored form of this expression? Remember to include the sign.

Correct! -3

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 9.2.2 and 9.2.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is -3. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. If \(x^2+2x+c\) is factored to be \((x \_\_\_\_\_)^2\), what is the missing value of the factored form of this expression? Remember to include the sign.

Correct! +1

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 9.2.4. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is +1. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. If \(x^2+14x+c\) is factored to be \((x \_\_\_\_\_)^2\), what is the missing value of the factored form of this expression? Remember to enter the sign.

Correct! +7

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 9.2.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is +7. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. If \(x^2−4x+c\) is factored to be \((x \_\_\_\_\_)^2\), what is the missing value of the factored form of this expression? Remember to enter the sign.

Correct! -2

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 9.2.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is -2. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. If \(x^2+24x+c\) is factored to be \((x \_\_\_\_\_)^2\), what is the missing value of the factored form of this expression? Remember to enter the sign.

Correct! +12

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 9.2.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is +12. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Mai is solving the equation \(x^2+12x=13\). She writes:

\(x^2+12x=13\)
\((x+6)^2=49\)
\(x=1\) or \(x=-13\)

Jada looks at Mai's work and is confused. She doesn't see how Mai got her answer.

Complete Mai's missing steps by answering questions a–d to help Jada see how Mai solved the equation.

\(x^2+12x=13\)

Step 1
\(x^2\;+\;12x\; +\) question a \(=\;13\;+\) question a

Step 2
\((x+6)^2=49\)

Step 3
\(\sqrt{(x+6)^2}=\sqrt{49}\)

Step 4
\(x+6= \pm\) question b

Step 5
\(x+6=\) question b

Step 6
\(x\;+\;6=\) \(-\)question b

\(x=1\) or \(x=-13\)

  1. What is the missing term in Step 1?

Correct! 36

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 9.2.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is 36. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. What is the missing term in Steps 4, 5, and 6?

Correct! 7

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 9.2.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is 7. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. What is the value of \(x\) in Step 5?

Correct! 1

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 9.2.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is 1. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. What is the value of \(x\) in Step 6?

Correct! -13

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 9.2.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is -13. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. For each equation in questions a–f, choose the equivalent equation with a perfect square on one side.
  1. \(x^2+8x=2\)

Correct! \((x+4)^2=18\)

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 9.2.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is: \((x+4)^2=18\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. \(x^2+10x=-13\)

Correct! \((x+5)^2=12\)

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 9.2.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is: \((x+5)^2=12\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. \(x^2−14x=5\)

Correct! \((x−7)^2=54\)

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 9.2.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is: \((x−7)^2=54\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. \(x^2+2x=0\)

Correct! \((x+1)^2=1\)

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 9.2.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is: \((x+1)^2=1\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. \(x^2+4x−5=0\)

Correct! \((x+2)^2=9\)

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 9.2.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is: \((x+2)^2=9\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. \(x^2−20x=-9\)

Correct! \((x−10)^2=91\)

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 9.2.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is: \((x−10)^2=91\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Solve each equation by completing the square, then choose the two roots.
  1. \(x^2−6x+5=12\)

Correct! \(x=-1\) and \(x=7\)

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 9.2.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answers are: \(x=-1\) and \(x=7\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. \(x^2−2x=8\)

Correct! \(x=-2\) and \(x=4\)

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 9.2.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answers are: \(x=-2\) and \(x=4\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. \(11=x^2+4x−1\)

Correct! \(x=-6\) and \(x=2\)

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 9.2.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answers are: \(x=-6\) and \(x=2\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Solve the equation \(x^2−18x+60=-21\) by completing the square.

Correct! \(x=9\)

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 9.2.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is: \(x=9\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

page.title: 9.2.6: Lesson Summary
page.contents:
In this lesson, you learned how to:

  • Explain what it means to "complete the square" and describe how to do it.
  • Solve quadratic equations by completing the square and finding square roots.

Here are the activities that helped you reach those goals:

  • 9.2.1: Different Forms of Perfect Squares
    • In this activity, you identified which expressions were perfect squares.
  • 9.2.2: Standard and Factored Forms of Perfect Squares
    • In this activity, you rewrote perfect squares given in standard form into factored form and vice versa.
    • 9.2.2: Self Check
    • 9.2.2: Additional Resources
  • 9.2.3: Completing the Square
    • In this activity, you solved quadratic equations using completing the square strategy.
    • 9.2.3: Self Check
    • 9.2.3: Additional Resources
  • 9.2.4: Making a Perfect Square
    • In this activity, you determined what needed to be added to a polynomial to make a perfect square trinomial.

After these activities, you completed the following practice:

  • 9.2.5: Practice

Checking In

On a scale of 1 to 5, how confident do you feel about the learning goals of this lesson?

Correct!

If you’ve answered 3 or less, be sure to reach out to your teacher before starting the next lesson.
